issue.title: Set sanitizer flags differently
issue.body: Sanitizer builds fail during linking, because sanitizer flags also need to be passed during linking.  It seems like the approach introduced in #652 using `add_compile_options` doesn't do that.  I tried using `add_link_options` but that didn't work, so I went back to what was working before #652.

comment.body:
> @dstebila could you try the latest commit?

Works for me.

issue.title: Only use hybrid level 1 KEMs in default curves list

comment.body: Looks good. Maybe we could trim the list even more, by keeping only one per family (e.g., only sikep434, not 503). What do you think?

issue.title: Only use hybrid level 1 KEMs in default curves list
Reduce number of default KEX algorithms
issue.body: Having a large number of default KEX algorithms is causing problems in software that expects a shorter list.  We should reduce the list of default KEX algorithms in TLS 1.3 to just the level 1 hybrids.

comment.body: See my comment on the PR: I'd think we should not limit OQS-openssl _this_ heavily. I'd think there is a way to keep supporting all algorithms that work OK in liboqs (splitting+run-time activating by NIST levels, splitting by  algorithm families, or any other idea to whittle down the list such as to not "overwhelm" downstream apps with an overly long list of "curves"/PQC algs).

issue.title: Run the test_kem and test_sig tests on a thread when possible
issue.body:
Algorithms with large stack usage cause problems when running in threads (e.g., #608, https://travis-ci.com/github/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-cpp/jobs/299650240).  This PR moves the tests in `test_kem` and `test_sig` onto a thread when compiling with clang or gcc, so as to detect these failures at the liboqs level, rather than leaving it to downstream sub-projects.

Note that the following schemes are currently failing:
```
Classic-McEliece-348864
Classic-McEliece-348864f
Classic-McEliece-460896
Classic-McEliece-460896f
Classic-McEliece-6688128
Classic-McEliece-6688128f
Classic-McEliece-6960119
Classic-McEliece-6960119f
Classic-McEliece-8192128
Classic-McEliece-8192128f
LEDAcryptKEM-LT52
Rainbow-IIIc-Classic
Rainbow-IIIc-Cyclic
Rainbow-IIIc-Cyclic-Compressed
Rainbow-Vc-Classic
Rainbow-Vc-Cyclic
Rainbow-Vc-Cyclic-Compressed
```

I'm not sure how to approach solving this.  Do we disable these algorithms by default?  Try to rewrite them so they're on the heap, rather than the stack?  Try to enlarge the stack in how all our subprojects are compiled so that they can be run (but then people might encounter this bad behaviour outside of our build)?

Advice welcome, @vsoftco @xvzcf @christianpaquin @thomwiggers @baentsch.

comment.body:
My immediate reaction: Disable them until they "behave"... (... incl. under pthreads). But then again, the great thing about `liboqs` and all libs/apps building on top is the availability to run all these algorithms (in different stages of "implementation hardening") side-by-side.

So what about this compromise: 
- Keep all algorithms in
- Keep adding them to downstream libs/apps like openssl
- Exclude the list above from pthread testing
- Document that exclusion clearly on the OQS website/git repo.
- Make the algorithm implementors aware of this problem so they can fix it (if they want to do that)

--> This way, we (OQS) can focus on what matters to all users: people can keep using any PQC they want courtesy `liboqs` -- until they hit such "snag". Fixing those "snags" can/and should be done upstream (it's not only "us"/`liboqs`-enabled SW stacks failing on this). E.g., wouldn't it be a nice addition to the PQClean project to require such 'pthreads' safety (and test for it) adding to the [prerequisites documented by PQClean](https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean#requirements-on-c-implementations-that-are-automatically-checked).

issue.title: Run the test_kem and test_sig tests on a thread when possible
issue.body:
Algorithms with large stack usage cause problems when running in threads (e.g., #608, https://travis-ci.com/github/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-cpp/jobs/299650240).  This PR moves the tests in `test_kem` and `test_sig` onto a thread when compiling with clang or gcc, so as to detect these failures at the liboqs level, rather than leaving it to downstream sub-projects.

Note that the following schemes are currently failing:
```
Classic-McEliece-348864
Classic-McEliece-348864f
Classic-McEliece-460896
Classic-McEliece-460896f
Classic-McEliece-6688128
Classic-McEliece-6688128f
Classic-McEliece-6960119
Classic-McEliece-6960119f
Classic-McEliece-8192128
Classic-McEliece-8192128f
LEDAcryptKEM-LT52
Rainbow-IIIc-Classic
Rainbow-IIIc-Cyclic
Rainbow-IIIc-Cyclic-Compressed
Rainbow-Vc-Classic
Rainbow-Vc-Cyclic
Rainbow-Vc-Cyclic-Compressed
```

I'm not sure how to approach solving this.  Do we disable these algorithms by default?  Try to rewrite them so they're on the heap, rather than the stack?  Try to enlarge the stack in how all our subprojects are compiled so that they can be run (but then people might encounter this bad behaviour outside of our build)?

Advice welcome, @vsoftco @xvzcf @christianpaquin @thomwiggers @baentsch.

comment.body:
The large stack-usage of some implementations is a long-known problem but I also don't know how to get around it (without large amounts of engineering effort). It sometimes helps to put the public keys/secret keys on the heap themselves; this allows the stack-based implementations that much more room on the stack. However, it's still going to be a problem.

> E.g., wouldn't it be a nice addition to the PQClean project to require such 'pthreads' safety (and test for it) adding to the prerequisites documented by PQClean.

I'm afraid that's not possible. PQClean bans any use of the heap to allow running implementations on platforms that don't offer an allocator. I'd prefer having more reference implementations, even if they have these kinds of problems.

issue.title: Only use hybrid level 1 KEMs in default curves list

comment.body:
> But I see a bigger issue now when looking at this code: With this, we really completely remove algorithms from `openssl` usage -- which isn't so great given what we currently have (the ability to run all candidates side by side, e.g., in performance as well as further downstream app tests, also against classic crypto of the same level).

No, we don't remove them fully from openssl usage.  They're just not the default algorithms.  You can run `openssl s_server -curves kyber1024 ...` and `openssl s_client -curves kyber1024 ...` and it will work fine.  You just have to explicitly enable these level 3 / 5 KEMs.  I thought this was the behaviour we were looking for.

When I run `circleci local execute --job ubuntu-bionic-x86_64` I get a bunch of connection failures (the CI tests above didn't do connection tests):

```
...
```

Hmm -- correct, connection tests are only done in the nightly runs to not delay a 'mostly working' (apparently not in this case) commit -- maybe we should change this, i.e., have at least one platform do the full connection test suite (?) -- takes more than half an hour by now, however due to the long list of algorithms.... suggestions welcome.

issue.title: Only use hybrid level 1 KEMs in default curves list

comment.body: Ah, OK -- then I read the code incorrectly. Thanks for the clarification! I'll better run the stuff before I comment :-(
I'll take a look about the failing test tonight. Yes, I think we should put at least a full connection test per commit. < 1h seems like an ok price to pay for these infrequent PRs.
Agree. Will you simply remove one of the `-noconn` from the checkin-test job in the `.circleci/config.yml` when doing the next checkin or shall I do a PR?

> Agree. Will you simply remove one of the `-noconn` from the checkin-test job in the `.circleci/config.yml` when doing the next checkin or shall I do a PR?

Probably best to do a different PR, just for scoping it to one purpose.
